item.title: In South Korea, Chinese Leader Cites Japan as Onetime Mutual Enemy
item.description: President Xi Jinping reminded South Koreans on Friday that their two countries had fought “shoulder to shoulder” against Japan more than four centuries ago.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China speaking in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Offices Reflect Growth of Busy Anticorruption Agency
item.description: Amid an intense antigraft campaign ordered by President Xi Jinping, China’s Central Commission for Discipline Inspection announced it had increased its offices by 36 percent, suggesting the secretive body’s existing resources have been stretched thin.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Wang Qishan, a member of the Politburo's Standing Committee, is leading China's anticorruption efforts.

item.title: Google Reinstates Some Links in Europe
item.description: The search giant has told The Guardian that several of the newspaper’s articles that had been scrubbed from some search results have been reinstated.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: Merkel Heads to China to Keep Alive ‘Golden Decade’ of Deals
item.description: Some experts are warning that the era of rapid growth in German-Chinese trade and dealings may be ending.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will make her seventh visit to China this weekend.

item.title: German Arrested on Suspicion of Passing Secrets
item.description: German media reported that the man, 31, worked for Germany’s intelligence service and is suspected of spying for the United States.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Andy Coulson Sentenced to 18 Months in Phone Hacking Case
item.description: Mr. Coulson, 46, a former editor in Rupert Murdoch’s news empire, was found guilty last week of one count relating to the hacking scandal.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Andy Coulson, former editor of The News of the World, arriving at the Old Bailey courthouse in London on Friday.

item.title: In Myanmar, Democracy’s Euphoria Losing Its Glow
item.description: More than three years after Myanmar’s ruling generals propelled the country on an ambitious journey toward democracy, security forces are back on the streets.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Make More Arrests in Huge Hong Kong Protest
item.description: Protest leaders say the police are trying to stifle dissent by carrying out arrests as pro-democracy groups plan more demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Calming the Tension Between Israel and the West Bank
item.description: The Israeli leader is uniquely positioned to calm tension in Israel and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Quarantine the Middle East
item.description: Shore up places like Kurdistan, Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, where governments have a chance of working.
item.dc:creator: By PHILIP D. ZELIKOW

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Persecution of Witches, 21st-Century Style
item.description: Far from being a horror from our medieval past, vigilante violence against those accused of witchcraft is very much still with us.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MITCH HOROWITZ

item.title: Jerusalem on Edge as Palestinian Teenager Is Buried
item.description: The funeral for Muhammad Hussein Abu Khdeir, widely presumed to have been killed in act of retaliation, was seen as a potential flash point.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Palestinian men climbed over a wall on Friday to avoid security checks on their way to Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem. Israeli forces blocked off streets around Jerusalem’s Old City and barred Muslim men under 50 from entering the mosque compound.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dance Troupe Taps Into Anti-Japanese Passions
item.description: A dance troupe in Beijing portrays heroic Chinese soldiers confronting the Japanese in a performance that reflects tensions between the two nations.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of amateur female dancers perform a patriotic dance during a performance in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Tycoon Pays Homage to a Fading Martyr
item.description: Chen Guangbiao draws the media spotlight again by paying respects at the grave of Lei Feng, the People’s Liberation Army martyr.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:description: The Chinese tycoon Chen Guangbiao visiting the grave of Lei Feng, a martyr of the People's Liberation Army.

item.title: German Parliament Advances a National Minimum Wage
item.description: The lower house overwhelmingly approved a minimum wage of 8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour, and the upper house is expected to follow next week.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: How Climate Change Could Foil China’s Smog-Fighting Efforts
item.description: China is spending a lot of money to address its air pollution problem, but some scientists say that may not produce the results the government expects.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: China is trying to reduce the heavy pollution that often strikes cities like Harbin in the northeast.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Relative Silence on Hong Kong Protests, Mainland Media Outlets Note Arrests
item.description: News outlets in mainland China have weighed in on Hong Kong’s pro-democracy march — to report on the arrests that followed it.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The police removed demonstrators on Wednesday morning from a sit-in that followed Hong Kong's pro-democracy march.

item.title: World Briefing: Gunmen in Somalia Kill a Lawmaker
item.description: Gunmen killed Mohamed Mohamud Heyd and his bodyguard in a drive-by shooting in Mogadishu, the capital, according to the police.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Anniversary in Egypt Draws Protests
item.description: Protesters held rallies in several Egyptian cities on Thursday in opposition to the military’s ouster one year ago of Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first fairly elected president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers’ Pay Dispute Is Resolved
item.description: Diplomats have resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Syria Aid Needed, Refugee Agency Says
item.description: The United Nations refugee agency said that 70 percent of its $3.74 billion emergency budget for helping Syrian war refugees remained unfunded, and it warned of “dramatic consequences.”
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Kurdish Officials Seek More Autonomy in Any Deal With a New Government
item.description: Leaders in Kurdistan have said they will not participate in a unified government unless Baghdad grants the region expanded self-rule and accepts the occupation of Kirkuk.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Soldiers with the Kurdish pesh merga at an outpost on the edges of the contested city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq. The city sits on substantial oil reserves.

item.title: News Analysis: Obama’s Blueprint for Fighting Terrorism Collides With Reality in Iraq
item.description: The seizing of large parts of Iraq by Sunni militants has laid bare the limitations of a terrorism policy that relies on the cooperation of often balky and overmatched partners.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Brazil Comes Around as the World Cup Plays On
item.description: The tournament has not produced the disasters some feared, and many Brazilians who were angry about lavish spending on the event cannot help getting caught up in its spirit.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Brazil supporters in Mogi das Cruzes watched their team play Chile last Saturday.

item.title: Teenagers’ Deaths Raise Fears of Shift From Political Struggle to Blood Feud
item.description: After four killings of young people, a familiar sense of foreboding was joined by a new kind of fear among Israelis and Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli said it had launched 15 airstrikes against sites in Gaza that are associated with Hamas.
